He studied sutras and treatises, and was diligent in the three karmas.

In the end of the Zhenguan era, there was a dove's nest in the eaves, raising two chicks.
Every time Mingdu would use leftover porridge to feed them in the nest, and he would chant the sutra, saying:
Relying on the power of this sutra, may you quickly grow feathers and wings.
Suddenly, they learned to fly early, fell to the ground and died together. Mingdu then buried them.
More than ten days later, he dreamed of two small children saying:

We were originally born as small creatures who laid eggs. We were raised and nurtured by the Venerable One, who recited and dedicated the merits. Now we have been reborn in the human realm, in a certain family ten li east of this temple.
Du silently recorded it. In the tenth month, he went to visit this family. The man and wife indeed gave birth to two sons.
He entered to see them. After a few days, he called out:
Pigeon children! They all turned their heads and responded.
After more than a year, they were able to speak and grew up.

Shi Qingxu, whose surname was Tang, was from Zizhou.
He had a rigid and decisive nature, and was difficult to control due to his rebelliousness. Suddenly he turned his mind to reciting the Diamond Prajna Paramita Sutra.
His three karmas were in harmony, without laziness.
Once, while reciting it in the mountains and forests, seven deer came to listen, as if they were listening attentively, and left when the sound and breath ceased.
Moreover, when a neighboring house caught fire, the entire row of houses was reduced to ashes, but the house of Xu was untouched by the flying flames, not even slightly scorched.

In the second year of Long'an, he traveled alone to Wuzhen Temple on the northern peak of the upper courtyard in Lantai. There was originally no well or spring, and it was too far to fetch water from the stream, so he had to carry it in pots and jars, which was extremely tiring.
At that time, Dharma Master Fazang of the Huayan Sutra heard about the miraculous efficacy of Xu holding the sutra, so he invited him to pray for a spring.
He immediately entered the Maitreya Pavilion, burned incense, and chanted the sutra through the night for three days.
Suddenly, he seemed to see three jade maidens in the northern mountain belly of the pavilion, using a dagger to dig the ground, and water flowed out immediately.
Xu carefully remembered the location and rushed to dig it, and sure enough, he obtained sweet spring water, which was inexhaustible.
In the fourth year, he sat through the summer at Shaolin Temple.
On the peak, there was a Buddha chamber that was very spacious, but no one dared to go there, saying that it was the dwelling of ghosts and spirits.

Once, a Vinaya master, relying on his observance of precepts, went there at night to recite the Vinaya. He saw a giant man stabbing him with a spear. He fled down the mountain in a panic and died shortly after.
Also, a monk who recited the Fire Head Vajra Mantra was highly respected by the assembly. They said to him:
Your mantra power is unmatched. Can you stay there overnight?
He said:
What is there to fear?
So he brought incense and fire, sat down, and recited the mantra.
Suddenly, the deity appeared and grabbed his feet, throwing him down the ravine. For seven days, he could not speak and was in a daze.
Xu Wen heard about this and said:
How dare the ghosts and spirits below act like this?
He then went there and recited the sutra as usual.
At night, he heard a very loud sound from the east of the hall. He then recited the Eleven-Faced Guanyin Mantra.
He also heard what sounded like two bulls fighting in the hall, and the Buddha images all shook.
When the spell lost its effect, he recited the sutra again, and the haunting and its effects immediately ceased.
Since then, no one living there has had any problems, and the spirit has moved away.
In the second year of the Shenlong era, he was ordered by imperial decree to pray for rain inside the palace.
After twenty-seven days, snow fell. Emperor Zhongzong thought it did not meet the people's expectations and ordered him to pray again at the temple.
He earnestly prayed inside the Buddha hall and burned a finger.
In just one night, rain covered a thousand li, and his finger returned to normal.

Biography of Shaokang of the Pure Land Temple on Mount Oulong in Mozhou, Tang Dynasty. Shaokang, whose secular surname was Zhou, was from Xiandu Mountain in Jin'un.
His mother, Lady Luo, had a dream of wandering on Mount Dinghu, where she received a blue lotus held by a jade maiden, who said:
This auspicious flower is entrusted to you. Later, you will give birth to a noble son. You must cherish him!
On the day of Kang's birth, blue light filled the room, and the fragrance was like a lotus flower.
By the time he was in swaddling clothes, his eyes were green, his lips were red, and his teeth had one of the Buddha's marks. He always sat upright with a smile on his face.
At that time, a good physiognomist in the village looked at him and said:
This child has the talent of a general. If he does not speak, I do not know.
When he was just seven years old, he was taken to Ling Shan Temple on the Buddha's birthday to pay homage to the holy countenance. His mother asked Kang:
Do you recognize him?
Suddenly he spoke:
Shakyamuni Buddha.
Everyone was surprised - he had never spoken before.
Thus his parents let him leave home to become a monk.
At the age of fifteen, he had already recited the five divisions of the canon. He received the precepts at Jia Xiang Temple in Yue Prefecture, and then studied Vinaya at Yi Temple.
After five summers, he went to Upper Yuan Longxing Temple to listen to the Huayan Sutra and the Yoga Treatise.

In the beginning of the Zhenyuan era, he went to the hall of Baima Temple in Luoyang and saw a light shining on an object. He then took it to see what sutra or Dharma it was, and it turned out to be Shandao's Text on Practicing and Guiding Western Pure Land.
Kang saw it with joy and chanted:
If I have a karmic affinity with the Pure Land, may this scroll's text glow again!
As soon as he made this vow, it indeed glowed brightly again, with countless transformed Buddhas and Bodhisattvas within it.
He then went to the hall of Shandao in Chang'an and made a vow.
He saw Shandao's true image transform into the body of a Buddha, who said to Kang:
If you follow my teachings to benefit and delight sentient beings, you will be reborn together in the Land of Bliss.
Kang was as if he had attained something. He went south to Guyuan Temple in Jiangling and met a Dharma master who said to Kang:
If you want to transform people, go directly to Xin Ding, the conditions are there.
After saying this, he disappeared, leaving only a fragrant light heading west.
When he arrived in Mu Jun, he entered the city to beg for food and got money. He encouraged the young children, saying that if they could chant Amitabha Buddha once, he would give them a coin.
Later, after more than a month, the children flocked to him, and those who chanted Amitabha Buddha more often were given money.
In this way, for a year, whenever boys and girls saw Kang, they would say Amitabha Buddha.

He then built a Pure Land practice site on UlÃ³ng Mountain, constructed a three-tiered altar, gathered people at midnight to practice, and sang praises in twenty-four sections, extolling the Pure Land.
Whenever it was a fasting day, they would gather in the clouds, and he transformed about three thousand people.

When he ascended the seat, he had his male and female disciples face Kang's mouth and loudly chant AmitÄbha Buddha. The Buddha emerged from his mouth, and they chanted ten times. The ten Buddhas were like a string of pearls. He said:
You have seen the Buddha's body and will attain rebirth.
In the tenth month of the twenty-first year of the Zhenyuan era, he instructed the assembly to stop and encourage them to diligently cultivate Pure Land practices.
After speaking, he sat in full lotus posture, his body emitting light, and passed away.
The sky changed, and a violent wind arose from the four directions, with a hundred birds crying in grief.
Wulong Mountain suddenly turned white.
His grave stupa is now on the Eastern Terrace Cliff in the state. After many years, only a square stone remains.
The soil beside the stone is said to cure illnesses. People in the state who suffer from various illnesses all burn incense, take the soil, and many recover after taking it.
The four corners of the stone are like cart tracks.
In the third year of the Qianyou era of the Han dynasty, Chan Master Deshao of Mount Tiantai rebuilt the stupa, which is still tall and grand today. At that time, it was called the Later Shandao.
The author says:

The verses and praises composed by Kang are all based on the sounds of Zheng and Wei, transformed and created, neither sad nor joyful, neither resentful nor angry, attaining the central tone and rhythm.
It is like a good doctor using sugar and honey to coat bitter medicine, enticing a baby to take it.
If it were not for a great being entering the provisional, how could he employ this expedient means to save the utmost?
Singing Buddha, Buddha with the Buddha's form emerging from the mouth, Shandao did the same to create Buddha's work, thus not a small cause and condition!

Tang Dynasty, Biography of Shou Su of Daxingshan Temple in Jingzhao, Biography of Shou Su of Daxingshan Temple in Jingzhao, Tang Dynasty, Monk Shou Su had a lofty nature and was different from the crowd.
He lived in Xingshan Temple in the capital and always regarded recitation and upholding as urgent tasks.
The courtyard was secluded, and there were four blue catalpa trees planted by Su himself.
During the Yuanhe period, many officials visited the courtyard.
In midsummer, the blue catalpa trees would sweat profusely, staining people's clothes with a greasy substance that could not be washed out.
At that time, Prime Minister Zheng Yu once went there with several officials to escape the heat, and disliked the dripping, saying to Su:
Disciple, I will cut down these trees for you and plant four pine trees instead, okay?
In the evening, Su jokingly cursed them, saying:
I planted you for over twenty years, and you are hated by people for dripping sweat, just like a hated tree that cannot be rested under.
If it happens again next year, I will definitely burn it.
Since then, there have been no more sightings.
Su vowed not to leave the temple and recited the Lotus Sutra 37,000 times.
At night, there were always weasels that would come and listen to the sutra.
During meal times, crows and magpies would come to take food from his hands.
Other monks tried to lure them with food, but the flock of birds became agitated and flew away.
In the early Changqing era, a monk named Xuanyou wrote a poem about this temple, saying:
30,000 Lotus Sutras in 30 springs, half my life I haven't stepped on the dust outside the temple gate.
At the time, this was considered a beautiful verse.
The end of Su's life is unknown.
The author says:
Those who prick lacquer trees always suffer from the few drops, because they love them and find them hard to get;
Those who cut down Wei trees suffer from their abundance of bitterness, because they hate them and find them easy to get.
Alas!
The sweating of the blue catalpa tree is rarely heard of in the world;
But when Master Su criticized and scolded it, the next year it disappeared.
How can there be a monastic disciple who is not as insentient as a tree or a plant?
If one cannot be like lacquer and keep oneself separate from defilement, or like salt and enhance the flavor of food,
if one only accepts the admonitions of teachers and friends and takes them to be perfect and pure,
The saying goes:
If there is a mistake, do not hesitate to change it.
In our teachings, we repent of our sins and purify ourselves, as if nothing has happened.
Think about it.
Biography of Tang Dynasty Huayan Monk of Youzhou, Biography of Tang Dynasty Huayan Monk of Youzhou, Shi Huayan, whose name is unknown.
He lived north of the city of Youzhou, always reciting the Huayan Sutra as his pure practice - at that time he was called by the complete title of the sutra.
When he recited it, the entire city could hear it, as if they were under the eaves.
In the Wansui Tongtian year, when Zhang Renyuan, the Duke of Han-guo, was the governor of Youzhou, he heard the sound of the sutra at night, the chapters and sequences were distinct.
And in the morning, he said to his wife:
The monk recited last night, it was as if he was in front of the yamen. Did you hear it or not?
His wife said:
How far is that place, that you could hear it?
Zhang Jun said:
If you don't believe it, you can each send a servant to ride a horse to check it out.
Sure enough, it was not a mistake.

Do you have any wishes that you would not report?

I am currently making five hundred kaá¹£Äya robes, intending to give them to arhats.

Do not go anywhere else, but send them to the monks at Bamboo Grove Temple on Mount Masan to the west of the prefecture.
He sent an envoy to carry incense and clothing to the Buddha's shrine. When he went up the mountain to look for Bamboo Grove Temple, there was not even a trace of it.
Thus, he deeply entered and climbed the high mountain, and saw an old man who asked him, saying:
Just follow me.

After a long time of spreading the teachings, he passed away sitting in meditation, and his physical body did not wither.
Many people in Fanyang often went to him for wishes, and there were signs of response.
The stupa was recently destroyed due to warfare.

If it is close, it is like the power of the good Dharma of vowing to uphold the sÅ«tra;

Shi Wenzhao, whose place of origin is unknown.
He was originally a simple and slow-witted person, but he was delighted upon seeing Buddhist images.
One day, he went to Baitai Temple, paid homage to the painted image of Dharma Master Tanyan, and left home to become a monk.
He recited various sutras single-mindedly, but did not know how to explain them. He was always frustrated by his dull faculties.
Suddenly, as if in a dream, he saw Dharma Master Tanyan, who was ten feet tall with piercing eyes, and said to Wenzhao:
What you desire, how can I bring it about?
I have a sutra called 'The Sutra of Wisdom,' seek it from there, and you will surely keep it. The response you will receive will be as easy as picking up a mustard seed from the ground!
He then took it out from his sleeve and gave it to him, which was the Diamond Prajna Paramita Sutra.
As soon as he climbed up and read it, he was startled awake after seven times, and the sutra was still in his eyes.
Afterwards, he remembered it without obstruction, as if he had practiced it for a long time.
The twists and turns and floating and sinking between his throat and tongue then changed into the proper rhythm, which was not the usual tune.
From then on, his intelligence was renewed day by day, and his eloquence was in his mouth. At that time, it was said that Avalokitesvara was attached to his body.
Moreover, he said:
My teacher was the national teacher of the Zhou and Sui dynasties.
Whenever he compiled commentaries, he would definitely receive divine instructions in dreams. I am not ashamed to be his disciple.
The Biography of Dharma-Illumination of Shaanxi in the Tang Dynasty, the Biography of Dharma-Illumination of Shaanxi in the Tang Dynasty, Shi Dharma-Illumination, whose place of origin is unknown.
His conduct was often rash, and he traveled without regularity.
In the first year of the Long-De era, he entered a lodging to avoid the rain. After a while, it turned very muddy and slippery. He did not get any alms food at noon.
He then scolded the servant to buy pork, cook some steamed buns, and roughly finish the meal, without any shame, as if no one was around.

At night, he recited the Diamond Sutra. Originally there was no oil lamp, but the entire room was illuminated, and strange fragrances filled the air.
All twenty-one guests came to pay homage and apologize, each donating clothes and money.
Zhao sat upright as if he saw nothing.
Later, it is unknown where he ended up.

They snatched away his bottle and hit it against a pine tree outside the temple. The bottle shattered with a loud sound, and the wine solidified and did not flow. It stuck to the tree like green jade, and no matter how much it was shaken, it did not scatter. When smelled, it had no smell.
The monks in the temple were astonished and asked him, What are you doing?

Biography of Wei Gong of Faxing Temple in Jingzhou, Tang Dynasty Biography of Wei Gong of Faxing Temple in Jingzhou, Tang Dynasty Lingrui Shi Wei Gong, it is unknown where he was from.
He left home at a young age to Faxing Temple, and was fond of associating with the low-ranking, often befriending those who did not follow the Dharma.
Although he deviated from the conduct of monks, he was diligent in reciting the Diamond Prajna Paramita Sutra, rarely leaving his lips.
Wine companions and gambling friends gathered at his door, engaging in empty deception, never feeling any shame.
Later, he encountered illness and was about to die.
In the same temple, there was Lingrui, whose behavior was similar to his, and they were called the two scourges of the temple.

One day, Lingrui went out, about one li away from the temple, and encountered six or seven young men, all very handsome, wearing fresh clothes, each holding musical instruments like those of the Kucha region. They asked Lingrui:
Where is the monk Wei Gong?
Lingrui told them his location, suspecting they were there to offer incense and praise the Buddha at the temple.
At dawn, he returned to the temple and heard the bell ringing, saying, Gong has passed away.
What he saw were heavenly musical instruments.
It is said that by the power of the sutra, he will definitely be reborn in the Pure Land. This also encouraged Lingrui.
Rui was enlightened and humbled himself. He was respected by the monastic community and eventually became highly accomplished.
The Biography of Sui Duan of Dejun Temple in Mingzhou, Tang Dynasty. Shi Sui Duan, whose surname was Zhang, came to Dejun Temple from an unknown place to seek a teacher.
As a person, he was honest and pure, and did not casually socialize.
His teacher taught him the Lotus Sutra, which he recited as if he had memorized it before. Everyone was amazed.
Even in old age, he was diligent and never slackened - he always chanted during the twelve periods of the day without stopping.
In the second year of the Xianshun era, he suddenly sat in full lotus position and passed away. Soon, seven blue lotus flowers emerged from his mouth.
People from far and near all rushed to see and pay respects.
The villagers, with a united heart, built a coffin and buried him under the Eastern Mountain.
More than twenty years later, the grave often emitted light. Later, when they opened it, his physical form was as if alive.
The assembly welcomed him back to the temple and decorated him with lacquer and hemp cloth.
Now it is called the True Body Hall and exists there.

As for the Yi Temple, it was originally the study hall of Kan Ze, the Grand Tutor of the Prince of Wu and Marquis of Du Xiang. Later, it was donated to become a monastery, and the title plaque took the character ze from Kan Ze's name. It is now the Puzhi Temple.
The author says:
The appearance of a lotus flower from the mouth at the end is indeed so!
It is said that when a wheel-turning king appears in the world, this flower grows in the ocean above the path. Could this happen in the present age of the image?
The author replies:
If it is a response to the person who evokes it, then it cannot be restricted by time.
It is like how the qilin is not a creature of the Central Kingdom, but it appears when there is an enlightened king.

Biography of Shenzhi of Baoshou Temple in Zhuchi, Yue Prefecture, Tang Dynasty Biography of Shenzhi of Baoshou Temple in Zhuchi, Yue Prefecture, Tang Dynasty Shi Shenzhi, a native of Yiwu, Wuzhou, with the secular surname Li.
The Li family's ancestors were descendants of Mu, a minister of the Yellow Emperor.
During the Han dynasty, there was Li Gui, the magistrate of Lu Commandery, who due to his official position resided in Yan and thus became a native of Lu.
His ancestors were all farmers, simple and honest.
Shenzhi had a pure and upright character from a young age, and earnestly enjoyed leaving the household life. He went to Yunmen Temple to be a disciple of Wei Xiao.
At the age of twelve, he ate only one meal a day.
He recited the Great Compassion Mantra and ascended the precepts according to the Dharma, with strict discipline and diligence.

Suddenly, during the Huichang period, the Dharma was destroyed. Although Shenzhi's appearance and attire were different, his vow to be a monk remained heavy. He did not become polished by grinding or dyed by soaking, as can be seen at that time.
In the first year of the Dazhong period, he resumed the path.
He traveled around Jiyang and examined the Chan chambers, saying:
The fish in the imperial pond, hidden in the marshes, are indeed!
This place is my marsh.
He always chanted water bowls to save people from hundreds of illnesses, and many were cured by drinking it.
The people followed suit, providing him with an incalculable amount daily, and called him the Great Compassionate Monk.
In the middle of the Dazhong era, he entered the capital. At that time, the Minister of State Affairs Pei Xiu of Shuping had a dream in advance that Zhi was coming. When they met, he was delighted.
The daughter of the Minister of State Affairs was possessed by ghosts and spirits. Zhi held a mantra for seven days and she recovered.

He then petitioned for the name of the temple, which was named Dazhong Shengshou. He was also given a bell from the Left Divine Strategy Army, a brocade painting embroidered by Empress Wu Zetian, and 5,000 scrolls of the canon.
Pei Xiu wrote the name plaque for the hall.
Zhi passed away in the twelfth month of the Guangqi era, the year of the Bingswu zodiac, on Mount Dongbai, at the age of 68, and 48 years as a monk.
His seat was moved back to Nanyue in Jiyang and he was interred in a pagoda.

Biography of Zong Shen of Chan Zhi Temple in Yangzhou, Liang Dynasty. Shi Zong Shen, whose clan and family are unknown, entered Chan Zhi Temple in Jiangdu in his youth. He renounced the householder life and recited tens of thousands of words of sutras.
The temple was the former palace of Emperor Yang of the Sui Dynasty.
